title: Kain panjang

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is blue
 with lighter blue and white designs. The kain panjang features large bouquets interspersed with birds and butterflies. On the left side of the batik
 the bouquet motifs are set against a dense patterned background
 with repeated floral blooms. The right side of the batik features a more sparse design
 with the bouquets set against a plain blue background.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) flower (motif) cultural diffusion

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  subject_terms_4: Kain panjang

  sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format
 comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  One side comprises large bouquets of carnations interspersed with butterflies and birds.  This buketan design is also applied to the other side although the large rose bouquets are surrounded by densely packed background patterns.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966)
 the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular
 exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality
 possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is blue, with lighter blue and white designs. The kain panjang features large bouquets interspersed with birds and butterflies. On the left side of the batik, the bouquet motifs are set against a dense patterned background, with repeated floral blooms. The right side of the batik features a more sparse design, with the bouquets set against a plain blue background.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  One side comprises large bouquets of carnations interspersed with butterflies and birds.  This buketan design is also applied to the other side although the large rose bouquets are surrounded by densely packed background patterns.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.
